intro: Sphaeralcea coulteri var. margaritae, commonly known as Coulter's globemallow, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States. It is characterized by its globular shape and bright yellow flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky soils and is adapted to arid environments. Its leaves are usually gray-green and covered in fine hairs, which help reduce water loss. It is a member of the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton.
